paper_title.en: Effects of Home Economics Lessons Focusing on Regional Food Cultures (Second Report) : Understanding the Food Culture Awareness Levels of Junior High School Students through their Written Reports

description.ja: Analyzing questionnaire responses of junior high school students, this study examined effects of food lessons that focus on regional dietary culture. The survey was conducted during the period of January through July 2005 and involved two groups. Group 1 was a group of junior high school students who took lessons on dietary culture taught by teachers who are members of the Kumamoto Prefecture Home Economics Circle. Group 2 was a group of students in the Kanto and Kumamoto regions who took lessons on the subject but were taught by teachers who were not members of the Circle. As a result of this survey, the followings were found: 1. A greater effect was found among Group 1 students regarding food-related topics from various contents and the methods of lessons compared to the other group of junior high school stu dents. 2. Group 1 students demonstrated the same levels of skills in food preparation as Group 2. 3. Group 2 students demonstrated changes in their way of living regarding nutrition, health, food preparation, and consumption. Group 1 students, in addition to the changes experienced by Group 2, demonstrated changes in the way they address environmental issues and food safety. Group 1 students also demonstrated an ability to put into practice a way of living guided by their own independent thinking and judgment.
description.en: Analyzing questionnaire responses of junior high school students, this study examined effects of food lessons that focus on regional dietary culture. The survey was conducted during the period of January through July 2005 and involved two groups. Group 1 was a group of junior high school students who took lessons on dietary culture taught by teachers who are members of the Kumamoto Prefecture Home Economics Circle. Group 2 was a group of students in the Kanto and Kumamoto regions who took lessons on the subject but were taught by teachers who were not members of the Circle. As a result of this survey, the followings were found: 1. A greater effect was found among Group 1 students regarding food-related topics from various contents and the methods of lessons compared to the other group of junior high school stu dents. 2. Group 1 students demonstrated the same levels of skills in food preparation as Group 2. 3. Group 2 students demonstrated changes in their way of living regarding nutrition, health, food preparation, and consumption. Group 1 students, in addition to the changes experienced by Group 2, demonstrated changes in the way they address environmental issues and food safety. Group 1 students also demonstrated an ability to put into practice a way of living guided by their own independent thinking and judgment.

paper_title.en: Effects of Home Economics Lessons Focusing on Regional Food Cultures (First Report) : Analysis of concept maps drawn by junior high school students

description.ja: Analyzing concept maps drawn by junior high school students, this study examined effects of food lessons that focus on regional dietary culture. The survey was conducted during the period of March through July 2005 and involved two groups. Group 1 was a group of junior high school students who took lessons on dietary culture taught by teachers who are members of the Kumamoto Prefecture Home Economics Circle. Group 2 was a group of students in the Kanto and Kumamoto regions who also took lessons on the subject but were taught by teachers who were not members of the Circle. As a result of this survey, the followings were found: 1. Awareness levels regarding food and dietary culture of Group 1 were the same as those of Group 2 regarding issues of nutrition and health, preparation and consumption, and food safety. However, Group 1 had a higher level of understanding regarding the relationship between food and the local region and its environment. 2. It was also found that Group 1's understanding was based on a broader foundation of knowledge and a realization of the interdependency among the key concept words regarding nutrition and health, preparation and consumption, the relationship between food and the local region and environment, and food safety. 3. Group 1 regarded the study of food to be of direct concern to themselves and life in their local region, through which they became aware of a variety of challenges relating to local living. This resulted in their drawing concept maps expressing their attempts to offer solutions to the challenges. From these findings, the author suggests that Group 1 students are developing a conscious intent to lead their own lives guided by their own thinking and judgment on these issues.
description.en: Analyzing concept maps drawn by junior high school students, this study examined effects of food lessons that focus on regional dietary culture. The survey was conducted during the period of March through July 2005 and involved two groups. Group 1 was a group of junior high school students who took lessons on dietary culture taught by teachers who are members of the Kumamoto Prefecture Home Economics Circle. Group 2 was a group of students in the Kanto and Kumamoto regions who also took lessons on the subject but were taught by teachers who were not members of the Circle. As a result of this survey, the followings were found: 1. Awareness levels regarding food and dietary culture of Group 1 were the same as those of Group 2 regarding issues of nutrition and health, preparation and consumption, and food safety. However, Group 1 had a higher level of understanding regarding the relationship between food and the local region and its environment. 2. It was also found that Group 1's understanding was based on a broader foundation of knowledge and a realization of the interdependency among the key concept words regarding nutrition and health, preparation and consumption, the relationship between food and the local region and environment, and food safety. 3. Group 1 regarded the study of food to be of direct concern to themselves and life in their local region, through which they became aware of a variety of challenges relating to local living. This resulted in their drawing concept maps expressing their attempts to offer solutions to the challenges. From these findings, the author suggests that Group 1 students are developing a conscious intent to lead their own lives guided by their own thinking and judgment on these issues.

paper_title.en: Papers about the Analysis of Teaching in the Journal of the Japan Association of Home Economics Education

description.ja: 91 papers about the analysis of teaching in the Journal of the Japan Association of Home Economics Education from Vol. 1 (1960) to Vol. 84 (1999), were discussed. The findings were as follows : 1. The rate of researches concerned with the analysis of teaching was 9.7% in Journal of the Japan Association of Home Economics Education. 2. There were many papers about food and clothing, in elementary, junior and senior high schools. In many papers, quantitative methods were used, and skills were studied. 3. We should expand to contents and schools. Then we should use the latest notable new quality methods for analysis of teaching.
description.en: 91 papers about the analysis of teaching in the Journal of the Japan Association of Home Economics Education from Vol. 1 (1960) to Vol. 84 (1999), were discussed. The findings were as follows : 1. The rate of researches concerned with the analysis of teaching was 9.7% in Journal of the Japan Association of Home Economics Education. 2. There were many papers about food and clothing, in elementary, junior and senior high schools. In many papers, quantitative methods were used, and skills were studied. 3. We should expand to contents and schools. Then we should use the latest notable new quality methods for analysis of teaching.
